trans-unit.source: How to create a VNet in the Azure portal
trans-unit.target: How to create a VNet in the Azure portal

trans-unit.source: To create a VNet based on the scenario above, follow the steps below.
trans-unit.target: To create a VNet based on the scenario above, follow the steps below.

trans-unit.source: From a browser, navigate to http://manage.windowsazure.com and, if necessary, sign in with your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: From a browser, navigate to http://manage.windowsazure.com and, if necessary, sign in with your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: Click **NEW** > **NETWORK SERVICES** > **VIRTUAL NETWORK** > **CUSTOM CREATE** as shown in the figure below.
trans-unit.target: Click **NEW** > **NETWORK SERVICES** > **VIRTUAL NETWORK** > **CUSTOM CREATE** as shown in the figure below.

trans-unit.source: Create VNet in portal
trans-unit.target: Create VNet in portal

trans-unit.source: On the **Virtual Network Details** page, type the **NAME** of the VNet, select its **LOCATION**, and then click on the arrow on the bottom right hand corner of the page to advance to step 2.
trans-unit.target: On the **Virtual Network Details** page, type the **NAME** of the VNet, select its **LOCATION**, and then click on the arrow on the bottom right hand corner of the page to advance to step 2.

trans-unit.source: The figure below shows the settings for our scenario.
trans-unit.target: The figure below shows the settings for our scenario.

trans-unit.source: Virtual network details page
trans-unit.target: Virtual network details page

trans-unit.source: On the **DNS Servers and VPN Connectivity** page, specify the name and IP address for up to 9 DNS servers to use.
trans-unit.target: On the **DNS Servers and VPN Connectivity** page, specify the name and IP address for up to 9 DNS servers to use.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify a DNS server, your VNet will use the internal naming resolution resolution provided by Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify a DNS server, your VNet will use the internal naming resolution resolution provided by Azure.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, we will not configure DNS servers.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, we will not configure DNS servers.

trans-unit.source: If you want to provide point-to-site VPN access to your VNet, enable the **Configure a point-to-site VPN** checkbox.
trans-unit.target: If you want to provide point-to-site VPN access to your VNet, enable the **Configure a point-to-site VPN** checkbox.

trans-unit.source: If you do not configure a point-to-site VPN, you can add it to your VNet at any time after creation.
trans-unit.target: If you do not configure a point-to-site VPN, you can add it to your VNet at any time after creation.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, we will not configure a point-to-site VPN.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, we will not configure a point-to-site VPN.

trans-unit.source: If you want to provide site-to-site VPN connectivity between your VNet and another VNet or your on-premises network, enable the **Configure a site-to-site VPN** checkbox and specify if you want to use **ExpressRoute** or note, and the name of the network to connect to.
trans-unit.target: If you want to provide site-to-site VPN connectivity between your VNet and another VNet or your on-premises network, enable the **Configure a site-to-site VPN** checkbox and specify if you want to use **ExpressRoute** or note, and the name of the network to connect to.

trans-unit.source: If you do not configure a site-to-site VPN, you can add it to your VNet at any time after creation.
trans-unit.target: If you do not configure a site-to-site VPN, you can add it to your VNet at any time after creation.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, we will not configure a site-to-site VPN.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, we will not configure a site-to-site VPN.

trans-unit.source: Click on the arrow on the bottom right hand corner of the page to advance to step 3.The figure below shows the settings for our scenario.
trans-unit.target: Click on the arrow on the bottom right hand corner of the page to advance to step 3.The figure below shows the settings for our scenario.

trans-unit.source: DNS Servers and VPN connectivity page
trans-unit.target: DNS Servers and VPN connectivity page

trans-unit.source: On the **Virtual Network Address Spaces** page, under **STARTING IP**, click on *10.0.0.0* to change the VNet address space, and then type the starting address space you want to use.
trans-unit.target: On the **Virtual Network Address Spaces** page, under **STARTING IP**, click on *10.0.0.0* to change the VNet address space, and then type the starting address space you want to use.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, type *192.168.0.0*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, type *192.168.0.0*.

trans-unit.source: Under **CIDR (ADDRESS COUNT)** select the number of bits for the subnet mask.
trans-unit.target: Under **CIDR (ADDRESS COUNT)** select the number of bits for the subnet mask.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, select *16 (65536)*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, select *16 (65536)*.

trans-unit.source: Under **SUBNETS**, click *Subnet-1* and rename the subnet if necessary.
trans-unit.target: Under **SUBNETS**, click *Subnet-1* and rename the subnet if necessary.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, rename it to *FrontEnd*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, rename it to *FrontEnd*.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you click outside the name textbox for a subnet you will not be able to edit the name if the subnet again.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you click outside the name textbox for a subnet you will not be able to edit the name if the subnet again.

trans-unit.source: To fix that, you need to remove the subnet by clicking on the X button to its right, then add a new subnet as described in step 13 below.
trans-unit.target: To fix that, you need to remove the subnet by clicking on the X button to its right, then add a new subnet as described in step 13 below.

trans-unit.source: Under **STARTING IP** for the first subnet, specify the starting IP address for the subnet.
trans-unit.target: Under **STARTING IP** for the first subnet, specify the starting IP address for the subnet.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, type *192.168.1.0*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, type *192.168.1.0*.

trans-unit.source: Under **CIDR (ADDRESS COUNT)** select the number of bits for the subnet mask for the first subnet.
trans-unit.target: Under **CIDR (ADDRESS COUNT)** select the number of bits for the subnet mask for the first subnet.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, select *24 (256)*.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, select *24 (256)*.

trans-unit.source: Click **add subnet** to add a new subnet, if necessary.
trans-unit.target: Click **add subnet** to add a new subnet, if necessary.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, add a subnet and repeat steps 10 to 12 to configure the VNet as shown in the figure below.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, add a subnet and repeat steps 10 to 12 to configure the VNet as shown in the figure below.

trans-unit.source: Virtual network address spaces page
trans-unit.target: Virtual network address spaces page

trans-unit.source: Click on the check mark button on the bottom right hand corner of the page to create the VNet.
trans-unit.target: Click on the check mark button on the bottom right hand corner of the page to create the VNet.

trans-unit.source: After a few seconds your VNet will be shown in the list of available VNets, as shown in the figure below.
trans-unit.target: After a few seconds your VNet will be shown in the list of available VNets, as shown in the figure below.

trans-unit.source: New virtual network
trans-unit.target: New virtual network
